contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox scientist |name = Marcel Deprez |image = Marcel Deprez ca1891.jpg |caption = |birth_date = {{birth date|1843|12|12}} |birth_place = [[Aillant-sur-Milleron]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1918|10|13|1843|12|12}} |death_place = [[Vincennes]] |residence = |citizenship = |nationality = [[France]] |ethnicity = |fields = |workplaces = |alma_mater = |known_for = [[HVDC]] [[electricity distribution]] |influences = |influenced = |awards = Awarded membership, [[French Academy of Sciences]] |signature = |footnotes = }} '''Marcel Deprez''' (December 12, 1843 – October 13, 1918) was a [[France|French]] [[electrical engineer]]. He was born in [[Aillant-sur-Milleron]]. He died in [[Vincennes]]. ==Biography== Deprez was born in [[Aillant-sur-Milleron]] in rural France and attended the School of Mines in Paris. He was not able to complete the course but he must have made a good impression as he was employed as a secretary to the Director of the school, [[Charles Combes]].<ref name=walters>[http://www.archivingindustry.com/Indicator/chaptereight.pdf The Engine Indicator], John Walters, Chapter 8, p.8-20</ref> At [[Creil]], from 1876 to 1886, Deprez conducted the first experiments to transmit [[electric power|electrical power]] over long distances. At the [[International Exposition of Electricity, Paris]] in 1881, Deprez undertook the task of presenting an [[electricity distribution]] system based on the long-distance transmission of [[direct current]]. The first successful attempt took place in 1882 from [[Miesbach]] to [[Munich]] at the occasion of the Exposition of Electricity in the Glaspalast organised by [[Oskar von Miller]]. There he transmitted 1.5 kW at 2kV over a distance of 35 miles.<ref name=arrillaga>{{cite book |page=page 1|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=I2mdgdflTQUC&pg=PA1|title=High Voltage Direct Current Transmission|isbn=978-0-85296-941-0|year=1998|publisher=Institution of Engineering and Technology (IET)|author=Jos Arrillaga|accessdate=2009-01-06}}</ref> Deprez conducted experiments in La Chapelle, Grenoble, Vizille, Paris, and Creil. He eventually attained [[Electric power transmission|transmission]] over thirty-five miles for industrial purposes. In 1889, [[Rene Thury]] continued his approach of arranging generators in series, eventually developing commercial systems delivering 20 Megawatts at 125kV over 230 kilometers.<ref name=arrillaga/> ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Cite book | publisher = Musée des arts et métiers | last = Girolamo Ramunni | title = La Revue n°23 - Juin 1998 | chapter = Machines électriques | accessdate = 2010-02-13 | chapterurl = http://www.arts-et-metiers.net/musee.php?P=157&id=10745&lang=fra&flash=f | language = fr }} * {{Cite web | title = Histoire de l'électricité.
